  "article_text": [
    "the binomial edge ideal of a graph was introduced , at about the same time , in @xcite and @xcite .",
    "let @xmath0 be a simple graph with the vertex set @xmath1 $ ] , edge set @xmath2 , and let @xmath3 $ ] be the polynomial ring , where @xmath4 is a field .",
    "the * binomial edge ideal * of @xmath0 in @xmath5 , which is denoted by @xmath6 , is generated by binomials @xmath7 , where @xmath8 and @xmath9 .",
    "moreover , this ideal is generated by a collection of 2-minors of a @xmath10-matrix whose entries are all indeterminates .",
    "some algebraic properties of this ideal were studied in @xcite , @xcite , @xcite and @xcite .",
    "also , in @xcite , the binomial edge ideal of a pair of graphs were introduced as a generalization of the binomial edge ideal of a graph .",
    "let @xmath11 be a graph on the vertex set @xmath12 $ ] and @xmath13 a graph on the vertex set @xmath1 $ ] , and let @xmath14 be an @xmath15-matrix of indeterminates .",
    "let @xmath16 $ ] be the polynomial ring in the variables @xmath17 , where @xmath18 and @xmath19 .",
    "let @xmath20 for some @xmath21 and @xmath22 for some @xmath23 . to the pair @xmath24",
    ", the @xmath25-minor @xmath26=x_{it}x_{jl}-x_{il}x_{jt}$ ] of @xmath27 is assigned .",
    "the ideal @xmath28 is called the * binomial edge ideal of the pair * @xmath29 .",
    "some properties of this ideal were also studied in @xcite . if @xmath11 is just an edge , then @xmath30 is isomorphic to @xmath31 .",
    "we study unmixedness and cohen - macaulayness of the binomial edge ideal of a class of chordal graphs , called generalized block graphs .",
    "hence , we generalize the result of @xcite about block graphs .",
    "also , we study the join and corona of two graphs .",
    "actually , we investigate about the relationship between unmixed and cohen - macaulay properties of the binomial ideal associated to the join and corona of two graphs , and the original graphs . this paper is organized as follows . in section  [ preliminaries ] , we review some definitions , notation and known results on the topic , which will be used throughout the paper . in section  [ binomial edge ideal of a class of chordal graphs ] ,",
    "we study a class of chordal graphs , called generalized block graphs , introduced previously by the authors in @xcite .",
    "we compute the depth of the binomial edge ideal of these graphs with respect to graphical terms .",
    "further , we determine all such graphs whose binomial edge ideals are unmixed and cohen - macaulay . therefore , we generalize the results appeared in @xcite , about block graphs . in section  [ join ] , we focus on the join of graphs .",
    "we give some necessary and sufficient conditions for unmixed and cohen - macaulay properties of the binomial edge ideal of the join of two graphs .",
    "we divide it to three different cases ; for two connected graphs , for one connected graph and a disconnected one , and for two disconnected graphs . also , we generalize the results of @xcite about a cone over a graph . finally , in section  [ corona ] , we study some properties of the binomial edge ideal of the corona of two graphs .    in this paper ,",
    "we mean by a graph , a simple graph . also , if @xmath32 is the vertex set of @xmath0 , then we denote it by @xmath1 $ ] . by the ring @xmath5 , we mean the polynomial ring in the variables @xmath17 , where @xmath18 and @xmath19 .",
    "if @xmath33 , then we consider @xmath5 to be the ring @xmath34 $ ] , for simplicity .",
    "in this section , we pose some notions and facts , which we need in the sequel .",

    "* proposition  4.1 ) let @xmath59 be integers and let @xmath11 and @xmath13 be connected simple graphs with @xmath60 $ ] and @xmath61 $ ] . then the binomial edge ideal @xmath30 is unmixed if and only if @xmath11 is complete and for all @xmath62 , one has @xmath63 .",
    "so , by combining these two propositions , one has the following , which will be used in this paper .",
    "[ unmixed3 ] let @xmath64 be integers and let @xmath11 and @xmath13 be connected simple graphs with @xmath60 $ ] and @xmath61 $ ] .",
    "then the binomial edge ideal @xmath30 is unmixed if and only if @xmath11 is complete and for all @xmath62 , one has @xmath63 .",
    "in this section , we study unmixed and cohen - macaulay properties of the binomial edge ideal of a class of chordal graphs , called generalized block graphs .",
    "indeed , we generalize a result of ene , herzog and hibi in @xcite .",
    "generalized block graphs were introduced in @xcite , as a generalization of block graphs . here , we recall the definition .",
    "a * nonseparable * graph is a connected nontrivial graph which does not have any cut points",
    ". a * block * of a graph is a maximal nonseparable subgraph of it .",
    "a * block graph * is a connected graph whose blocks are cliques . here , by a clique ,",
    "we mean a complete subgraph of a graph .",
    "one could see that a graph @xmath0 is a block graph if and only if it is a chordal graph such that every two maximal cliques of it intersect in at most one vertex . this class was considered in  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  1.1 ) . recall that @xmath65 is the clique complex of the graph @xmath0 , the simplicial complex whose facets are the vertex sets of the maximal cliques of @xmath0 .",
    "now , let @xmath0 be a connected chordal graph such that for every three maximal cliques of @xmath0 which have a nonempty intersection , the intersection of each pair of them is the same . in other words , @xmath0 has this property that for every @xmath66 , if @xmath67 , then @xmath68 . we call @xmath0 , a * generalized block * graph .",
    "thus , it is clear that all block graphs and hence all trees are also generalized block graphs . for example , the graphs depicted in figure  [ generalized2 ] and figure  [ generalized1 ] are generalized block graphs which are not block graphs . here ,",
    "by a * cut set * of a graph @xmath0 , we mean a subset of vertices of @xmath0 whose deletion increases the number of connected components of @xmath0 .",
    "moreover , by a * minimal cut set * of @xmath0 , we mean a cut set which is minimal under inclusion .",
    "one could see that a subset @xmath69 of the vertices of a generalized block graph @xmath0 is a minimal cut set if and only if there exist @xmath70 such that @xmath71 , and for all other facets @xmath72 of @xmath65 , @xmath73 . in this case",
    ", we sometimes say that @xmath69 is a @xmath74-minimal cut set of @xmath0 .",
    "now , recall that the * clique number * of a graph @xmath0 , denoted by @xmath75 , is the maximum size of the maximal cliques of @xmath0 .",
    "let @xmath0 be a generalized block graph on @xmath1 $ ] .",

    "each leaf @xmath72 has at least a free vertex .",

    "while unmixedness and cohen - macaulayness of the binomial edge ideal are equivalent for block graphs , this is not true for generalized block graphs , as it is shown in the next theorem . since it is known that the binomial edge ideal of a graph is unmixed if and only if the binomial edge ideal of its connected components are unmixed , here we focus on the connected case :    [ unmixed - generalized ] let @xmath0 be a connected generalized block graph on @xmath1 $ ] .",

    "the _ corona product _ @xmath470 of two graphs @xmath97 and @xmath0 is defined as the graph obtained from @xmath97 and @xmath0 by taking one copy of @xmath97 and @xmath471 copies of @xmath0 and joining by an edge each vertex from the @xmath213-th copy of @xmath0 with the @xmath213-th vertex of @xmath97 . for each @xmath472",
    ", we often refer to @xmath473 for the copy of @xmath0 connected to @xmath35 in @xmath470 . for example",
    ", figure  [ corona1 ] shows the graph @xmath474 and figure  [ corona2 ] depicts the graph @xmath475 .            as a special case , when @xmath0 is just a vertex",
    ", @xmath470 is exactly @xmath476 , i.e. the graph which is obtained from a graph @xmath97 by adding a whisker to each of its vertices , whose some properties of the ( monomial ) edge ideal have been studied . for example , it is an interesting fact that the ( monomial ) edge ideal of a graph , obtained by adding whiskers to each vertex , is always cohen - macaulay .",
    "but , one could deduce from theorem  [ cm - corona ] that the binomial edge ideal of such a graph is cohen - macaulay if and only if the original graph is complete . in the sequel",
    ", we use the following , for simplicity :    suppose that @xmath97 and @xmath477 are connected graphs on disjoint sets of vertices @xmath111 $ ] and @xmath201 $ ] , respectively .",

    "_    let @xmath97 and @xmath477 be connected graphs on disjoint sets of vertices @xmath111 $ ] and @xmath201 $ ] , respectively . if @xmath422 , then @xmath478 is just an edge .",
    "if @xmath237 and @xmath423 , then @xmath478 is the cone of a vertex on the graph @xmath477 , which was studied in section  [ join ] and also in @xcite .",
    "now , we focus on the other cases .",
    "the following theorem determines those graphs whose binomial edge ideal of their corona is cohen - macaulay and unmixed .",
    "[ cm - corona ] let @xmath97 and @xmath477 be connected graphs on disjoint sets of vertices @xmath111 $ ] and @xmath201 $ ] , respectively , where @xmath247 , @xmath535 .",
    "then the following conditions are equivalent : + _ ( a ) _",
    "@xmath526 is cohen - macaulay .",
    "+ _ ( b ) _",
    "@xmath536 is unmixed .",
    "+ _ ( c ) _ @xmath97 and @xmath477 are complete .",
    "\\(a ) @xmath246 ( b ) is well - known .",
    "+ ( b ) @xmath246 ( c ) follows by lemma  [ whisker1 ] , lemma  [ unmixed1-corona ] and lemma  [ unmixed2-corona ] , which will be proved in the sequel . indeed , suppose that @xmath536 is unmixed .",
    "if @xmath238 , then the result is clear from lemma  [ whisker1 ] .",
    "if @xmath423 , then by lemma  [ unmixed1-corona ] , @xmath519 is unmixed , since with the notation of lemma  [ unmixed1-corona ] , we have @xmath33 and @xmath537 .",
    "then , by lemma  [ unmixed2-corona ] , unmixedness of @xmath519 and @xmath536 yields that @xmath97 and @xmath477 are complete graphs .",
    "+ ( c ) @xmath246 ( a ) note that @xmath538 could be seen as the graph obtained from gluing each vertex of @xmath539 to a vertex of a copy of @xmath540",
    ". then the result follows by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  2.7 ) and the fact that @xmath541 and @xmath542 are cohen - macaulay .",
    "[ whisker1 ] let @xmath0 and @xmath97 be connected graphs on disjoint sets of vertices @xmath12 $ ] and @xmath1 $ ] , respectively , where @xmath543 .",
    "then the following conditions are equivalent : + _ ( a ) _",
    "@xmath544 is cohen - macaulay .",
    "+ _ ( b ) _",
    "@xmath545 is unmixed .",
    "+ _ ( c ) _ @xmath0 and @xmath97 are complete and @xmath33 .",

    "hence , @xmath460 and @xmath586 , which contradicts the assumption @xmath252 .",
    "thus , we get that if @xmath561 is unmixed , then @xmath477 is complete .",
    "now , assuming @xmath97 and @xmath477 are both complete , we show that @xmath561 is unmixed if and only if @xmath33 .",
    "since we supposed that @xmath477 is complete , case  ( i ) does not occur .",
    "so , by case  ( ii ) and using proposition  [ unmixed3 ] , we have @xmath561 is unmixed if and only if @xmath587 if and only if @xmath33 , since @xmath588 .",
    "thus , we get the desired result ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we study unmixed and cohen - macaulay properties of the binomial edge ideal of some classes of graphs . </S>",
    "<S> we compute the depth of the binomial edge ideal of a generalized block graph . </S>",
    "<S> we also characterize all generalized block graphs whose binomial edge ideals are cohen - macaulay and unmixed . </S>",
    "<S> so that we generalize the results of ene , herzog and hibi on block graphs . </S>",
    "<S> moreover , we study unmixedness and cohen - macaulayness of the binomial edge ideal of some graph products such as the join and corona of two graphs with respect to the original graphs. </S>"
  ]
}
